Title.evidence: Randomised Controlled Trial of Accelerometry-Based Motion Detectors in Brachial Plexus Reconstruction

Trial_Design.evidence: In this randomised controlled trial, five male patients, with an average age of 41 years, underwent nerve transfer for brachial plexus injury.

Participants.evidence: five male patients, with an average age of 41 years, underwent nerve transfer for brachial plexus injury.

Intervention.evidence: Participants wore bilateral accelerometry-based motion detectors for 7 days.

Objective.evidence: This study investigates the efficacy of accelerometry-based motion detectors in evaluating functional outcomes following nerve transfer.

Method_Outcome.evidence: The primary outcomes were the time of use ratio (VT) and magnitude ratio (VM) of the affected arm compared to the unaffected arm.

Randomisation_Allocation.evidence: The randomisation and allocation concealment methods were not specified

Number_Randomised.evidence: five male patients, with an average age of 41 years, underwent nerve transfer for brachial plexus injury.

Result_Outcome.evidence: The VT for the affected side compared to the unaffected side was 0.73 (±0.27), and the VM was 0.63 (±0.59).

Harms.evidence: No adverse events were reported during the study.

Trial_Registration.evidence: Trial registration and funding details were not provided.

Funding.evidence: Trial registration and funding details were not provided.
